div.p: We construct universal twists connecting the centrally extended double Yangian 𝒟⁢Y⁢(s⁢l⁢(2))c𝒟𝑌subscript𝑠𝑙2𝑐caligraphic-D italic-Y OPEN:( italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y}(sl(2))_{c} with deformed double Yangians 𝒟⁢Yr⁢(s⁢l⁢(2))c𝒟subscript𝑌𝑟subscript𝑠𝑙2𝑐caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}}(sl(2))_{c}, thereby establishing the quasi-Hopf structures of the latter.

p.span: On the quasi-Hopf structure of deformed double Yangians

D. Arnaudona𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, J. Avanb𝑏FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b}, L. Frappata𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, É. Ragoucya𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}, M. Rossia𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a}

p.em: a𝑎FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-a FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{a} Laboratoire d’Annecy-le-Vieux de Physique Théorique LAPTH
CNRS, UMR 5108, associée à l’Université de Savoie
LAPP, BP 110, F-74941 Annecy-le-Vieux Cedex, France
b𝑏FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-b FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{b} LPTHE, CNRS, UMR 7589, Universités Paris VI/VII, France

div.p: MSC number: 81R50, 17B37
LAPTH-773/00
PAR-LPTHE 00-01
math.QA/0001034
January 2000

Universal twists connecting (affine) quantum groups to (elliptic) (dynamical) (affine) algebras have been constructed in [1, 2, 3]. They show in particular the quasi-Hopf structure of elliptic and dynamical algebras. These twists transform the universal R𝑅italic-RR-matrix ℛℛcaligraphic-R{\cal R} of the first object into the universal R𝑅italic-RR-matrix ℛℱsuperscriptℛℱcaligraphic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{\cal R}^{\cal F} of the second one as follows:

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: The double degeneracy limits of elliptic R𝑅italic-RR-matrices, whether vertex-type [4, 5, 6] or face-type [7] give rise to algebraic structures which have been variously characterised as scaled elliptic algebras [5, 6], or double Yangian algebras [7, 8, 9]. As pointed out earlier [4, 6]111We wish to thank S. Pakuliak for clarifying this point to us., although represented by formally identical Yang–Baxter relations R⁢L⁢L=L⁢L⁢R𝑅𝐿𝐿𝐿𝐿𝑅italic-R italic-L italic-L RELOP:equals italic-L italic-L italic-RRLL=LLR [10], these two classes of objects differ fundamentally in their structures (as is reflected in the very different mode expansions of L𝐿italic-LL defining their individual generators) and must be considered separately.

In our previous paper [7] we have defined, in the quantum inverse scattering or RLL formulation, various algebraic structures of double Yangian type connected by twist-like operators, i.e. such that their evaluated R𝑅italic-RR-matrices were related as:

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: for a particular matrix F𝐹italic-FF. It was conjectured that these twist-like operators were indeed evaluation representations of universal twists obeying a shifted cocycle condition thereby raising the relation (1.2) to the status of a genuine twist connection (1.1) between quasi-Hopf algebras.

We shall be concerned here only with algebraic structures related to the algebra s⁢l⁢(2)^csubscript^𝑠𝑙2𝑐OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\widehat{sl(2)}_{c}, and henceforth dispense with indicating it explicitly: for instance 𝒟⁢Y𝒟𝑌caligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} is thus to be understood as 𝒟⁢Y⁢(s⁢l⁢(2)^c)𝒟𝑌subscript^𝑠𝑙2𝑐caligraphic-D italic-Y OPEN:( OVERACCENT:widehat ARG:start italic-s italic-l OPEN:( NUMBER:2 CLOSE:) ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){{\cal D}Y}{(\widehat{sl(2)}_{c})}.

It is our purpose here to establish such connections, at the level of universal R𝑅italic-RR-matrices, between the double Yangian structures respectively known as 𝒟⁢Y𝒟𝑌caligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y}, 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}}, 𝒟⁢YrV⁢8𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}} and 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}}. 𝒟⁢Y𝒟𝑌caligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} is the double Yangian defined in [9, 11]. 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} is characterised by a scaled “elliptic” R𝑅italic-RR-matrix defined in [4], 𝒟⁢YrV⁢8𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}} is characterised by a scaled R𝑅italic-RR-matrix defined in [6, 5]. In connection with our previous caveat, note that these R𝑅italic-RR-matrices are also used to describe respectively the scaled elliptic algebras 𝒜ℏ,0subscript𝒜Planck-constant-over-2-pi0caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}_{\hbar,0}, 𝒜ℏ,ηsubscript𝒜Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝜂caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi PUNCT:, italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal A}_{\hbar,\eta} [5, 6, 4]. 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}} is the deformed double Yangian obtained by a particular limit of the dynamical R𝑅italic-RR-matrix characterising elliptic ℬq,p,λsubscriptℬ𝑞𝑝𝜆caligraphic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q PUNCT:, italic-p PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal B}_{q,p,\lambda}} algebra [7].

A crucial ingredient for our procedure is a linear (difference) equation obeyed by the twist. This type of equation for twist operators was first written in [12]. It is also present in [2, 3]. Our method consists in i) finding a twist-like action in representation ii) interpreting this representation as an infinite product iii) defining a linear equation obeyed by this infinite product iv) promoting this linear equation for the representation to the level of linear equation for universal twist. v) The solution of this linear equation is obtained as a infinite product as in [2] which vi) is then proved to obey the shifted cocycle condition as in [2, 3] and vii) has an evaluation representation identical to the twist-like action found in i).

This provides us with the universal R𝑅italic-RR-matrix and quasi-Hopf structure of the twisted algebras 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6,V⁢8,F𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6𝑉8𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 PUNCT:, italic-V NUMBER:8 PUNCT:, italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6,V8,F}}, thereby realising a fully consistent description of these algebraic structures.

The universal R𝑅italic-RR-matrix and Hopf algebra structure for 𝒟⁢Y𝒟𝑌caligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} were described in [9, 11]. We construct a universal twist between 𝒟⁢Y𝒟𝑌caligraphic-D italic-Y{{\cal D}Y} and 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}}. We then show the existence of a universal coboundary (trivial) twist, the evaluation of which realises the connection between the evaluated R𝑅italic-RR-matrices of 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} and 𝒟⁢YrV⁢8𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉8caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V8}}, leading to identification of these two as quasi-Hopf algebras. Finally another universal coboundary-like twist realises, when evaluated, the connection between the R𝑅italic-RR-matrices of 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} and 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}}.
It follows that the three deformed structures are in fact one single quasi-Hopf algebra described by three different choices of generators, more precisely given in three different gauges.

We shall denote throughout this paper ℱ⁢[𝒜;ℬ]ℱ𝒜ℬcaligraphic-F OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:]{{\cal F}}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}] the universal or represented twist connecting R𝑅italic-RR-matrices as ℛℬ=ℱ21⁢[𝒜;ℬ]⁢ℛ𝒜⁢ℱ12-1⁢[𝒜;ℬ]subscriptℛℬsubscriptℱ21𝒜ℬsubscriptℛ𝒜superscriptsubscriptℱ121𝒜ℬcaligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:] caligraphic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ caligraphic-A PUNCT:; caligraphic-B CLOSE:]{{\cal R}}_{{{\cal B}}}={{\cal F}}_{21}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}]\;{{\cal R}}_{% {{\cal A}}}\;{{\cal F}}_{12}^{-1}[{{\cal A}}\,;{{\cal B}}].

div.p: It is important to point out that L+superscript𝐿italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endL^{+} and L-superscript𝐿italic-L POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endL^{-} are independent. There exists in this case a Gauss decomposition of the Lax matrices allowing for an alternative Drinfeld presentation [11].

The evaluation representation πxsubscript𝜋𝑥italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\pi_{x} is then easily defined by its action on a two-dimensional vector space by

math.alttext: e^{\pm}(u)\equiv\pm\sum_{\begin{array}[]{c}{\scriptstyle k\geq 0}\\ {\scriptstyle k<0}\\ \end{array}}e_{k}u^{-k-1}\,,\qquad f^{\pm}(u)\equiv\pm\sum_{\begin{array}[]{c}% {\scriptstyle k\geq 0}\\ {\scriptstyle k<0}\\ \end{array}}f_{k}u^{-k-1}\,,\qquad h^{\pm}(u)\equiv 1\pm\sum_{\begin{array}[]{% c}{\scriptstyle k\geq 0}\\ {\scriptstyle k<0}\\ \end{array}}h_{k}u^{-k-1}\,.

div.p:
It would be tempting to relate the automorphism τ𝜏italic-tau\tau to the one used in [3], although the naive scaling of the latter does not give back the former. For instance our τ𝜏italic-tau\tau is inner not outer.
All the infinite products are logarithmically divergent. They are consistently regularised by the Γ1subscriptΓ1Gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{1} and Γ2subscriptΓ2Gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Gamma_{2} functions. In representation, (5.5) is equal to the scaling limit of the represented twist from 𝒰qsubscript𝒰𝑞caligraphic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal U}_{q}} to 𝒜q,psubscript𝒜𝑞𝑝caligraphic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q PUNCT:, italic-p POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{{\cal A}_{q,p}} [3, 7].
Note that this case is similar to the gauge transformation used in [15] although g𝑔italic-gg is not purely Cartan.
It follows that

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:8 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] RELOP:equivalent-to italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) caligraphic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] Delta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g CLOSE:) italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p:
satisfies the shifted Yang–Baxter equation (4.11).
To recover (5.1), use (5.5) and remark that πx⊗πx⁢(g⊗g)tensor-productsubscript𝜋𝑥subscript𝜋𝑥tensor-product𝑔𝑔italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g MULOP:tensor-product italic-g CLOSE:)\pi_{x}\otimes\pi_{x}(g\otimes g) commutes with R⁢[𝒟⁢Y]𝑅delimited-[]𝒟𝑌italic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y CLOSE:]R[{{\cal D}Y}].

section.h2: 6 Twist to 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}}

div.p: The R𝑅italic-RR-matrices of 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} and 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}} are related by:

semantics.annotation: italic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where

semantics.annotation: italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:6 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:tensor-product italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ATOM:with italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( ARRAY:start ROW:start CELL:start italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-beta ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-r ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CELL:end CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end ROW:end ROW:start CELL:start NUMBER:0 CELL:end CELL:start italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-beta ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-r ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CELL:end ROW:end ARRAY:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Again, one identifies V′⁢(β)superscript𝑉′𝛽italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:)V^{\prime}(\beta) as the evaluation representation of an algebra element

semantics.annotation: italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-beta CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-pi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: where

semantics.annotation: italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 italic-r ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: One then defines the following shifted coboundary

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) MULOP:tensor-product italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: It obeys a shifted cocycle condition

math.alttext: {\cal K}_{12}(r)\;(\Delta^{\cal F}\otimes\mbox{id}){\cal K}(r)={\cal K}_{23}(r% +c^{(1)})\;(\mbox{id}\otimes\Delta^{{\cal F}^{\prime}}){\cal K}(r)\;,

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) OPEN:( Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product ATOM:id CLOSE:) caligraphic-K OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals caligraphic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) OPEN:( ATOM:id MULOP:tensor-product Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) caligraphic-K OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) PUNCT:,
{\cal K}_{12}(r)\;(\Delta^{\cal F}\otimes\mbox{id}){\cal K}(r)={\cal K}_{23}(r% +c^{(1)})\;(\mbox{id}\otimes\Delta^{{\cal F}^{\prime}}){\cal K}(r)\;,

div.p: with ℱ23′⁢(r)=ℱ23⁢(r+c(1))subscriptsuperscriptℱ′23𝑟subscriptℱ23𝑟superscript𝑐1caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) RELOP:equals caligraphic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:23 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r ADDOP:plus italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\cal F}^{\prime}_{23}(r)={\cal F}_{23}(r+c^{(1)}), as a consequence of

semantics.annotation: OPEN:( Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:tensor-product ATOM:id CLOSE:) Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( ATOM:id MULOP:tensor-product Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) Delta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-g POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: which is the coassociativity property for ΔℱsuperscriptΔℱDelta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start caligraphic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta^{\cal F}.
Finally

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] RELOP:equivalent-to caligraphic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:21 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:) caligraphic-R OPEN:[ caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] caligraphic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-r CLOSE:)

div.p: satisfies the shifted Yang–Baxter equation (4.11). Moreover, (6.8) together with (6.5) show that 𝒟⁢YrF𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝐹caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-F POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{F}} and 𝒟⁢YrV⁢6𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑟𝑉6caligraphic-D italic-Y POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V NUMBER:6 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end{{\cal D}Y_{r}^{V6}} are the same quasi-Hopf algebra.
